"Higher density of dots means a higher probability the electron being there". Even though this is a very popular interpretation of the wave-particle duality, the phrases like that should not be understood literally. This is not because there is no "probability", this is because there is no "being". A more certain and usual formulation is "the probability of finding the particle at a given point". The problem with this formulation is: there is no "finding". We can only talk about the probability of some measurable result of some experiment. "Finding" is a metaphor suggesting that the exact location of a particle does exist, but is inherently stochastic, so we know only the density of the probability of "finding" it for each given point. But what's the experiment to observe the "finding"? The correct interpretation is different: the exact location itself does not exist. We can only indirectly confirm the shapes of the wave function because the theory correctly predicts the experimental results, and this is all that matters. But, fundamentally, we cannot "inspect" the location of a quantum object without the modification of its state.

Ummm . . . if you want a picture of where the electron is and how fast it's going, you clearly don't understand how atoms and quantum mechanics work for numerous reasons. First, particles are not extremely tiny spheres. They are excitations in energy fields that permeate the entire universe. Second, the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle tells us that the more you know about a particle's momentum, which is directly related to its velocity,  the less you know about its position and vice versa. Third, because of quantum tunneling, quantum teleportation, and nonlocality, electrons dont always exist in the orbitals of atoms. An electron can briefly exist in the nucleus. It can travel to the other side of the universe. It can pop in and out of the atom whenever it likes. Finally, particles are not carried along energy fields the way that little specs of dust are carried along water.

Я утверждаю,что пространство это время.А время это пространство.Пространство и время тождественны.Это одно и то же.Нет времени без пространства,и нет пространства без времени.Для преодоления пространства требуется время/затрачивается время.Для осознания времени требуется пространство/преодоление пространства.Когда вы смотрите вдаль/на что-то вдали,вы видите время,требуемое для его преодоления до объекта на котором ваш взор.При этом кто-то скажет что в этот момент я его не преодолеваю.Это так.В этот момент его преодолевает электромагнитная волна - свет,которая "доносит" до вас не только свет,но и "осознание" пространства-времени.Кто-то скажет,я закрою глаза,и отключив визуализацию пространства,которое "несёт" мне свет,я по идее должен остановить и время.По идее да,но в этот момент ваше сердце гонит кровь,по венам,которая преодолевает пространство,ограниченное кровеносными сосудами,затрачивая на это время.Пространство-время прямопропорционально зависит от приложеной энергии для его преодоления.Когда вы идёте пешком оно имеет одну величину.Когда вы увеличиваете энергию преодоления,например едете на автомобиле,время-пространство сокращаются,и так далее.Для каждого,начальная константа личного пространства-времени,определяется личными биологическими процессами.Но они не сильно различаются,так как природа индивидуумов одна и та же,при этом усредняется придумаными механизмами.Например часами.Я утверждаю,что этот прибор,измеряет приложеную энергию на преодоление пространства-времени.

Um, no, this is not how they look like. This is a mathematical model that describes a way to model atoms. Sheesh. I wouldn't say it is better either... it's just a different way to think about models. All of science is a model based on a set up axioms which may or may not be true and which there is no way to prove them because PROOF only a mathematical/logical concept and is only meaningful in a logical system. Everything we do intellectually as humans is based on models we create of the universe.... those models are not real. The only thing that is real is the universe. But as we learn more about the universe using our models we learn our models are not perfect so look for better models... but almost inevitably always think our current model is the actual universe. In fact, it is likely that our models become counterproductive.

I mean, all you are doing is representing points of orbitals with spheres... nothing special and really adds zero to any intellectual understanding and ultimately is just a discretization of space which is quite common to do. After all, every point plot is the same idea. I don't see any real benefit from doing this except that it's cool to see. In fact, I've seen this in papers 50 years old except they were just 2D static black and white plots which almost are likely due to not having sophisticated plotting capabilities.

The point I'm making here is that it isn't a better way... it's the same way. It's like saying a point plot of a line plot is a better way to visualize a line plot and pretend it's some great new discovery. Oh sure, it will bring in the ad revenue so that everyone has to pay more at the store and people that really have no idea of science will thing it is unlocking some secret to the universe but it's really nothing special. Now if they somehow actually offered some insight in to how the internals of atoms really worked(such as if they revealed something new such as how atoms interacted with each other at the sub-atomic level then it might be something useful). Else this is just taking something already well know for many decades and putting a new coat of paint on it and calling it new(which happens to be extremely common but relatively useless because it's mostly hype).

Actually, in your most simplistic terms. It's quite easy to picture what an atom looks like. If you think about what is involved in looking at something on a macro level scale, what you see is light reflected off the object. If you could zoom in and see light reflecting off an atom, which isn't possible in the traditional sense, then what you would see is a weird semi-reflective semi translucent cloud. What that cloud looks like would be reflective of its environment and it's structure. How reflective in translucent it would be would be reflective of how many electrons are in those particular orbitals. So in other words, it would be like a fuzzy mirror scattered in a weird cloud. Even in black and white light it would look quite psychedelic. The intensity of the reflected light would be proportional to the probability of an electron being at that location in the cloud. This is something that could actually be rendered by a program. If you had an intense enough laser source, and enough atoms and you were able to correlate the measurements, you could actually generate a probabilistic image of what this would look like. It's basically how they visualized the photon.

Sadly, even these brain-friendly representations are woefully inaccurate. That's because these "visual models" fail to represent 3 important aspects of electrons:

o Physical representation. As you know, so-called "electrons" are not actually particles in a quantum sense. They're simply a maximum average point of energy in a field of energy that forms the various "cloud" shapes around the nucleus of atoms. So it's a bit like looking at sunlight reflecting off of a surface and asking "where are the particles located?" Or looking at a field pattern of magnetism and asking "where are the particles located?" It's just too abstract. We may be better off asking: "which point of a reflected surface is measurably the brightest". Or, which spot in a given magnetic field is yields the highest magnetic strength?" Those questions get a lot closer to what these "electrons" actually represents in their orbital field clouds. So seeing them represented as a moving mass of small particles is not much different than seeing water in an ocean wave represented as a moving mass of individual particles. Helpful? Maybe.

o Speed. The speed of a so-called "electron" in its orbital shell or "wave cloud" is not really depicted, other than as a slow moving mass of individual particles. (I believe electron speed was one of the items on your wish list). In reality, the speed of electrons in their orbital shells is close to the speed of light (depending on the medium). Thus, the movement of a so-called "electron" (remember, its just a maximal value in an energy field) is so fast to human perception as to be considered statically "everywhere at once" (much like sunlight). So if you could visualize a beam of sunlight, made up of photons, but shaped like one of these electron cloud formations, then you would be much closer to reality.

o Size. There is also no sense of proper size or scale of the electron in relation to the 'wave cloud' in which it is shown or the nucleus upon which it orbits. In reality, the size of an electron (average maximal point of energy) is so infinitesimally small in relation to the immense distance between it and the nucleus in the quantum scale. For example, a hydrogen atom consists of a single proton and a single electron. If this single proton was the size of a ping pong ball at the center of the atom, then we the farthest we would expect to find the electron would be about 4,040 ft away (about 13-1/2 football fields away) in its orbital shell. And since the diameter of an electron is about 1/1000 of a proton, when compare with the scale of the ping pong ball, the size of the electron would be about 1/1000th of 1.5 inches, which is far less than the thickness of a human hair in relation to the ping pong-sized proton to which it orbits.

And look, I get it. You're animated 3D models were shooting for a different way to visualize the standard orbital clouds by bringing them to life. So its a difficult problem to tackle. But I do applaud your efforts to try to represent something that is mostly conceptual to our human scale macro sensibilities to give it more of a 'tactile feel'.

This video has good simplification of a way to visualize electron orbital clouds: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BPkcDWLBsrI

And I think one of the best representations of atoms, as a group, that I've ever seen was in a 3D visualization of an actual atomic lattice structure. And while that did not attempt to depict the inner structure of an individual atom as you are doing, it did give a very real sense of the way in which atoms bind together to form the basic elements as a 3D rotating lattice stitched together from many images taken from an electron scanning microscope: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yqLlgIaz1L0

At this level, quantum fuzziness dominates the shape of things. Also, Lorenz factors further reshape things at relativistic speeds. At the end of the day, atoms all fill space in volumes approaching a sphere. Tunneling microscopes demonstrate this clearly. The electron orbitals primarily determine the chemical reactions between atoms.

This video shows the correctness of the Madelung-Bohm concept, according to which there are stationary flows of a certain medium inside the atom, and it is the movements of this medium that determine all the macroproperties exhibited by the particles and the atom. In Russia, this concept was developed by Vladimir Atsyukovsky from about the 50s of the 20th century, who came to this independently and only later learned about the work of Madelung. As an engineer, Atsyukovsky in his work encountered a number of inconsistencies between electromagnetic calculations and actual measurement results, and, not satisfied with the assumption of errors that turned out to be too large with fairly accurate and thorough experiments, he began to study the initial work of Maxwell, and then his predecessors and followers. In the process of this study, he came to the conclusion that the rejection of the universal world medium was, at the very least, premature, and the return to it led to the creation of a simple mechanistic model, similar to the one that Madelung got mathematically. At the same time, the application of this model allowed to obtain error-free results in the original work and led to several special experiments showing its validity.
In the same vein, a depiction of our solar system would more accurately appear like a DNA strand as it moves through the galaxy.

This made me dive into the sizes of particles.
And turns out, a photon is about 17 times larger then an electron and about 26 times smaller then a proton.
Not to mention, an ectron absorbs a photon when it gets hit, and jumps to a higher energy state (the average light photon has about 2 times the energy of the average electron btw)
Therefore, we physically cant see electrons in tge traditiomal "see" way, because they dont reflect light nor produce it.
They do release radiation when falling to a lower level though. So theres that.

As a computational chemist who spends quite a lot of time working with atomic orbitals, I found this video extremely interesting. I guess that the 3d visuals of balls moving in space are actually quite closely linked to these so-called "fuzzy clouds". In fact, an alternative (stationary) way of representing a fuzzy cloud, is to draw it as a collection of dots, where the density of dots corresponds to the probability of finding an electron at a given location. Here, we've just got 3d balls instead of dots, but other than that it is the same idea.

The fact that the balls are in motion nicely illustrates the idea that when an electron is closer to the nucleus, it is likely to move faster - if the potential energy is more negative, the kinetic energy will be correspondingly more positive. This is in fact why relativistic effects are important in heavier atoms: when the electron is close to the nucleus of a heavy atom, it's speed can approach the speed of light, meaning that classical quantum mechanics breaks down and one needs to use the Dirac equation (or an approximation of it) to correctly describe what's going on.

While I agree a model of some scientific process is just that, a general model that does not capture the full nature of the phenomena and is innately incomplete, I would (subjectively) argue that a model still needs to capture some basic information, and valence/ electron count are I would say more important in that respect (3D model). I will agree though, this model is incredibly useful for 99.8% of things outside a higher level undergrad physics course and supplementing it with your diagram takes the cake. Bohr's postulates :
1. Electrons revolve around the nucleus in circular paths
2. The electrons revolve in a energy shells or orbits named as K, L, M, N.. or numbered 1, 2, 3, ...
3. Electrons, when they revolve neither lose nor gain energy, hence the orbits are also called stationary orbits.
4. Electrons revolve in the orbits with a certain angular momentum(product of moment of inertia and angular velocity), this angular momentum is always an integral multiple of h/2pi.

L = nh/2pi

n = principal quantum number
h = planck's constant
L = angular momentum
5. Electrons release energy as they jump to higher orbits and absorb it as they jump to lower orbits.
The absorbed or released energy is given by dE = E2 - E1 = hv.

v = nu

6. As the value of "n" increases the size and energy of the orbit increases.

Sorry but 0:40 and 4:09 (versions of the electron cloud) are bad representations. All they convey is what a probability pattern looks like visually - an actual atom "looks" nothing like an electron cloud. The TRUE representation of the atom is the traditional nucleus with single point electrons surrounding it. The electron cloud concept is still useful because it gives a different view (and different information), but let's not confuse probability with actuality.

As cool as those are, they don't show the reality. Yes, you can represent excited states for the hydrogen atom and other orbitals with different quantum numbers, but since we're talking about a hydrogen atom, it only has one electron, and thus only one orbital can exhist when you excite the electron, and are accurately represented here. But in every other element, more than one orbital exhist at the same time. How does that complex sum of orbitals adds up to a real atom with more than one electron? What are their sizes relative to one other? Do they overlap in any way? I know the wave function shapes are obtained by calculation for the hydrogen atom and multi-electron atoms are nearly impossible to calculate, but to this day I haven't found a decent explanation or depiction of the image that multi-electron atoms would generate, accounting all its orbitals exhisting at the same time.

As a physicist, there are so many misleading things in this picture I can hardly begin to tackle it. Electrons don't have a definite size. They're not 'balls'. Their waveform distribution is not rough, it's completely smooth. If this is supposed to represent shot noise, then why does each point exist and move continuously through time, rather than coming on and off constantly? Electrons don't 'move' around the atom with a fixed speed like that, it is a wavefunction more accurately depicted by a vibrating drum with a fixed orientation. This is going to confuse people alllll over again.

An electron is "guided" by an electromagnetic field. Nothing more, nothing less. It is not guided by any "wave." If it were, then this alleged "wave field" would be a new force field acting on the electron. The "wave field" is a mathematical construct to describe its probabilistic behavior, which is caused by real forces (gravity, electromagnetism, etc).

I do not believe that an electron or other subatomic "particles" exist as BB-like or marble-like dots or spheres flying in or around an atom. The orbital shape is the shape of the electron's space-time and so the orbital shape is the shape of the electron. The orbital is NOT a shaped volume of space where a discrete particle might probabalistically be found. The quantum of energy that is the electron is shape-shifting. The electron changes shape.

My twopenn'orth. IMO Trying to imagine what things 'look like' in the limit of modern physics is counter-productive. We have evolved to think about the world in certain ways because of the way our bodies interact with the world. We imagine things to be 'particles' because we understand how stones (and apples) behave. We can grasp the idea of 'waves' too because we experience such things commonly. But when we have to deal with the particle-wave duality our brains can't cope. We have no referent.
The same is true of space time. We think we have a grasp of space, time and gravity - but the twists and turns of 4 dimensional spacetime in a gravitational field is impossible for us to grasp in any intuitive sense.
I think most physicists these days have had to admit to themselves that trying to create mental images of reality outside of our own domain inevitably leads to error and misunderstanding. It's not just unhelpful, it's harmful. The best we can do is to use symbolism, that is mathematics. Just trust that and let go of the 'need to know'.

I am not sure I would have the electrons orbiting in these diagrams. There is actually no way to know for certain how electrons move within an orbital, but we do know they do not move in classical orbits. Since this is accelerated motion orbits would have to be faster than the speed of light (not allowed) or they would decay and crash into the nucleus. In some respect it is probably better to imagine the electrons randomly popping from location to location within the orbital without crossing the distance via something like tunneling. They may not do that either, but it is better than having orbits in my opinion.

If I were to rewrite the animation I would have one (or two, if it is a filled orbital) solid electron moving location according to the probabilities of the orbital, and it would have a fading "tail" for previous locations. With the right fade-out you would get a shadow image that roughly matched the electron density of the orbital as the electron moved within it. That would be much more accurate.

These orbitals are only what you would get if you made a measurement with some preferred orientation (they are eigenfunctions). In reality the electron will typically be in a superposition of many states, and when you make a measurement you force the wave function to collapse to one of these eigenfunction orbitals. In other words, those strange donut shaped will align themselves to your measurement coordinate system.

原子之间的距离与原子尺寸也像太阳系一样，恒星之间距离遥远，原子之间也有“遥远（相对于原子尺寸）”的距离。那么在强大压力下，原子间距可以被压缩，释放压力以后他们大概率是会复位。气体分子就更明显，压力减小体积增加，如果没有地球引力，大气会飞向四面八方的宇宙，因为这些分子有能量（自身旋转和震动）。重金属原子相互引力较大，在宇宙中优先聚集，即便在很高压力下，如地核，原子之间也是有空间的。物质之间既有引力，但排斥力（原子保持所在空间大小的惯性）更是普遍存在。飞碟UFO的材料可能利用的是物质间的排斥力（超导？），它可以在它周围任意方向制造引力（运行前方）或排斥力（后方）。

Atoms are a MODEL, a mathematical representation of the smaller parts of everything. Atoms have no shape since there is no medium to show that shape. What is the smell of 1 single molecule of vinegar (CH3COOH)? It has no smell. Only the accumulation of a large enough dose of acetic acid has a smell since our olfactory system reacts to it for some peculiar reason.
What does an atom look like? We cannot know, since light particles are of comparable size as electrons. If the smallest thing you can 'see' is a basketball, how will you 'see' a golf ball? You cannot. So you come up with mathematical formula's that give some kind of acuteness.
Like one of my professors used to say: Schrodingen didn't have a clue what his formula meant. He just posted a sleek looking differential equation and it turned out to be 'correct'.
The 'great' Einstein that shouted to Bohr, when he ran out of logic "God does not roll dice".
It ain't rocket science. You cannot see the ultra small and neither can you see the ultra big.

However, how are they really different from traditional atomic orbital (AOs) diagrams which have orbital probability clouds (s, p, d, f) ? The inflow through the axis of spin -- and outflow at the equator, at HIGH velocities - is what creates the shape that you see here -- and because the outflow is actually physical and collides with other particles attempting to approach towards it, they get repelled by the onslaught of outflowing charge photons.  Except in cases where the inflows of two nuclei are aligned such that they are not impeding each other but rather becoming modules of each other and allowing that charge field of particles to flow in the most optimal way.  Anything that blocks that inflow gets blasted by the weight of the particles surrounding it until the flow is restored

This is actually showing the charge field around the atom, not the electron, which contrary to the mainstream theory, are really not the main aspect of the energy state. according to charge field theory, it's photons, or charge photons, which simply push electrons along in their motion and flow. However, the only thing missing in your visual model which I like a lot, is that the flow of particles around the nucleus, don't simply orbit it, but flow through the poles and are hurled outward at the equatorial plane. It all gets sucked in at north and south, and spit out at a slight angle at the equator forming an outflow of two hemispheres.

If your model showed the particles getting sucked in and spun outward that would be the most accurate model to date, IMO.

Electrons would just be pushed by that flow towards the "holes" of the magnetic / spin axis -- but can't fit through -- so, they don't fit through lol. They just get pushed towards an area where they allow the inflow to happen while doing the least amount of work.

One small suggested change from an art perspective:

Having one particle (electron) in the cloud highlighted with a separate colour, and making the rest of the particles semi-transparent. Very Nice for using de Broglie-Bohm formulation!
But I would describe the wave-particle concept in pilot-wave, and a wave and its peaks as the particles - I mean technically the "speck" is the stuff of electron wave in a most general sense, right?
I mean there's no need for a physical objectification, when the peaks are all we need.
Think about it this way - we have some very advanced instruments for detection of elementary particles, but they're not absolutely perfect, they have (generally speaking) "sensitivity".
Ie if electrons are waves (which we know they are at least sometimes) then it's possible that sometimes (or somewhere) they're just the tiniest waves on the "surface" of the EM field, so tiny that are below our instruments' detection capability. But as all waves they can interfere constructively and sublimate in these places reaching levels we can easily detect ... and Bam - we say - There! It's a particle!
My point is our whole measurement instruments are basically filters, that filter out waves with amplitudes lower than our instruments' sensitivity, and we only see the peaks above that sensitivity level ... completely unaware of the waves and events under that threshold.
To actually see that concept (if haven't imagined it well already) google "FloWave Ocean Energy Research Facility" or another similar wave-laboratory, and you can see how the tiniest of waves can produce a peak of water (or generally speaking energy) that's many, many times higher.

Imho de Broglie-Bohm pilot theory is the most underrated theory ever!

0:48 Electrons don't orbit the nucleus. If they did they would slowly lose energy and collapse into the nucleus. I know you mention Bohmian Trajectories so you know the jury is still out. What we perceive as electrons only exist when the wave function collapses to a point in 3 dimensions. And it's still debatable whether the location of the 3d electron is dependent upon the viewer not the electron. In other words an electron is a standing wave and it's area extends off to infinity. That's how just one particle can interfere with itself in the double slit experiment. Just one "electron" is big enough to span the gap between the slits. You could argue depicting an electron in 3D is to misrepresent what an electron actually is. We as humans simply can't perceive what they truly are. I guess what I'm driving at is restricting an electron to 3 dimensions is hiding the fact quantum entangled particles occupying some higher dimension can extend far beyond even a 3D orbital "cloud". It's entirely possible you would need a computer screen the width of the universe to truly represent what an electron really is. Perhaps there is just one "electron", i.e. an electron field. To represent it in 3d is to hide what it is.

Sorry but you just did some nice plots of the orbitals. As a physicist, you must know that under a central force the probability of finding an electron at a given radius from the nucleus is the same, regardless the angular coordinates. In other words, any isolated atom has spherical symmetry. It looks like this https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S000926140901015X-gr1.jpg
The different colors correspond to the electron shells. The quantity depicted is a lower bound to the momentum of the electron, which is maximum at the nucleus. In atomic units, the velocity at the nucleus is equivalent to the atomic number, v=Z thanks to Kato's cusp theorem.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cplett.2009.08.034

This is wrong. There are no "electrons" as particles until the wave function collapses. Before that, there's only a probability function. These images, which seem to depict electrons in specific places, conflate the notion of probability (of the electrons ending up in specific places when the wave function collapses) with the ensuing result of the wave function collapsing. The real problem here is probability - it's seemless. There are no specific points in probability. The traditional shapes are more realistic.

Electrons are constantly trying to get away from the atom.  There are no "opposites attract" or "mystery energy" keeping the electron and proton separate.  The proton constantly reacts to the electron trying to escape which it why the electron has a jagged, rough orbit.  Electron Orbitals prove it.  Electrons flow smoothest in a straight line at its own speed. However, when electrons are forced to accelerate, electromagnetism occurs.  Similarly, when Electrons orbitals are pushed closer to the proton due to an overload of neutrons, radiation occurs since the electrons have to exert more power to try to escape. (Uranium)....but all this is just a theory of mine....I remember getting a bunch of D's in Physics classes.

In any case, a paradigm shift is needed, because if the information storage theory is true, what we're doing currently with atoms is like listening to the mobile phone frequency bands, but only focusing on the spectrum image, not the calls themselves. it's pretty and all, but this still doesn't answer Schrodinger's question about how an electron travels from one point to the next. This only displays the potential position and also a theoretical movement.

The most rational explanation of the random point movement of the electron within an atom was actually given by Wilhelm Reich, you know that guy who had his books and research burned in the late 1940's by the FDA, as well as having a restraining order put against him for his experimentation into what he described as Orgone energy. He described the process of movement as more like a jellyfish which compresses and expands, you know pretty much how all observable things work, through a rate of induction over the propelling of something, but I digress.

This gives compression and expansion gives a far better reason to why when measured Schrodinger was capable of seeing an electron here, then an electron there until he was able to give an image of the shape of an atom. Where just basic rotational models in no way give any form of explanation to how an electron has the ability to jump from one area of space to another.

But then again, when you have a following of a theory (which holds no references) which states that all things are particles, then you often "get lost following equation after equation until you no longer have any basis of reality" thanks N. Tesla for that observation.

Still hats off to the awesome observation of the visualization of what balls moving around something are. If you really want to blow your mind, have everything moving in a 3 dimensional s curve which compresses and expands, then see what your model looks like :D, should show you the aspect that Schrodinger missed in his mapping of the atom. I also gives you a more rational understanding of why you get donuts, and different colours, as pending on the rate of compression and expansion will determine which spectrum of light is observed.

To add to the complexity, keep into account that these orbitals are only valid for the neutral hydrogen atom, and these orbitals are only "visually correct" for that atom. When we have more than one electron, we cannot represent the orbitals analytically (e.g. with an exact mathematical formula). However, we can use the hydrogen atoms orbitals as the "primary colors" to represent the more nuanced orbitals of larger atoms, more or less (with a vast approximation in the analogy) how we combine red green and blue to produce any color. The truth is not the orbitals. The truth can be described using the orbitals.

IMHO, the whole problem in describing electron motion around an atom's nucleus is the misuse of the term "orbit" itself, which when most people hear the word "orbit" they immediately think of satellite orbits around larger massive bodies like a moon orbiting a planet or the planets orbiting the star.

I prefer to think of electron motion around an atom's nucleus as 'clouds' – or more precisely, probability clouds. I think this more accurately portrays the life of an electron as it jumps about an atom's nucleus. A cloud can be up close and personal or it can be lofty and remote. It's all a matter of the energy relationship between the electron and the atom's nucleus.

The way I understand atomic orbitals is that since electrons exhibit wave-like properties, electrons being near each other in the atom has their wave interact in multiple different ways. These interactions amplify themselves and suppress themselves in different spots, giving rise to the orbitals' shapes, where suppressed waves explain the areas where it's not possible to find electrons. This also explains why Hydrogen has a "solid" spherical orbital with no gaps, because there's only one electron, so no interference.

It's the same phenomenon as Chladni plates, but in 3d.
Not to be picky, but rendering the electron clouds with alpha would go a long way to help people understand each dot is not an electron.

I would like to add that these are not the shape of atoms, but rather the shape of specific orbitals for one specific element. It represents the probability density of an electron, which depends on its quantum numbers. And since the real atomic wavefunction is a linear combination of many states, the atom is all of these orbitals at the same place at the same time. Where the electron is we don't know. What we know is in which orbital it is, and the density probability of that particular orbital. But as soon as you add another electron, or as soon as any other atom is in place, then you get a linear combination of each specific orbital and this image falls apart. This is a great visualization, but unfortunately the atom is way more complicated.

Hmm... I mean, it's pretty. And it does communicate something about atoms. But it leaves out a huge portion of understanding of what an atom is, what an electron is, what the orbitals and their energy levels actually mean and why they exist in discrete forms like that with gaps in between.

I'm not 100% sure how to do a better visualization but I think you could push it to the next level by first showing this... then showing a standing wave illustration in a box or the like, then showing how by being orbits, those standing waves become (roughly) circular and yet are still constrained in terms of boundary conditions, so ultimately you have another animation of an atom as sort of a "bag of wobbly-wavey wave rings".

And then you could combine them in a couple of different ways. A simple overlay could be one. Then maybe take the "bag of waves" image and fuzzify/spherificate it to incorporate some of the fuzzy ball-of-balls visual from this video. And finally take the fuzzy ball-of-balls viz and show the balls following constrained wavelengths and gradually blurring them until they become the waves of the other one?

I dunno, I just feel like a big piece of why the orbitals are shaped how they are needs an understanding of the effective boundary conditions that give rise to the discrete nature of the allowed orbitals, and this graphic really doesn't convey that at all. It also didn't seem to do much to represent the fact that each orbital doesn't have its own exclusive region of space.

So... nice progression on the path toward a better visualization of an atom, but... sadly I'm not sure this is the end of that journey. But it is a really promising idea that could definitely have a place in that final representation.

Well this is without a doubt a beautiful rendition and gives some kind of an idea what different orbital configurations might look like in 3D space (especially due to these low probability density areas). But to use it as an academical depiction of an atom it needs quite some rework. The rendition gives off two false notions: those blobs aren't electrons (even though it was mentioned in the video) and the spatial scale is out of proportion. I'd like to think of it as a cloudy grayish transparent round portion of space, which can deform and expand, based on different electron configurations taking up different metric of space. A cloudy ball? For reference I also recommend molecule isodensity images. An atom is (probably) not like this very spotty and patterned thing. These models are based on hydrogen, who has 1 electron. Literally 1. Is it really correct to depict 1 electron atoms like this? With hundred spots similar to electrons, but not really being them. It's kinda ironical to promote a better/simpler visualization of atoms and then use wave function in the video to clarify the depiction and not really showing atom as an real unit itself, but a 3D model of probability density. For most people who have not studied chemistry in at least undergrad, this is already too complex to fully grasp. And without understanding the underlying statistical idea, it just comes off as if this is what atoms look like. Very grainy blobs.

Nevertheless it's really an awesome rendition! Didn't mean any harm with my comment, just trying to fuel the conversation on this topic. Atomic orbitals deserve a lot more attention than they currently get.

See, the thing with electron diagrams is that they're not intended to portray how electrons in atoms actually are, and that's entirely necessary because when not being interacted with, electrons don't really "orbit" the nucleus at all, and they don't really have a definite location at any point in time.

The wavefunction diagrams don't show where electrons likely are, they show where the electrons are likely to be when they are interacted with. Thus, even they don't provide an accurate representation of the structure of an atom.

These do look extremely lovely and thank you for the great video.   I would very much enjoy seeing what the transition between orbitals looks like with these simulations!  That said, one doesn't really need to do Bohmian dynamics to get a feel for orbital dynamics in quantum mechanics.  As implied in the very end, if one generated "smoke-rendered" cloudy Schrödinger wave functions as density visualizations, but kept the phase information and ran it dynamically, keeping track of the real and imaginary parts as colors, you'd get the same basic pictures.  Another advantage to the Schrödinger approach is that it is a linear PDE that can be solved at the sophomore level in analytical form for hydrogen.  The de Broglie–Bohm approach, while incorporating the Schrödinger equation, is non-linear and not so accessible in closed form.  Finally, with the de Broglie–Bohm approach one is left with the tension of why the apparently literally orbiting "non-electron electron particles" in the simulation aren't radiating and may create more confusion -- this mystery was one driving motivation for early quantum theory and the Schrödinger equation in the first place.

What orbitals depict is not the electron but the interaction of its quantum field.

How would you visualize standing waves on a drumhead? Or sound waves in a closed room? It's exactly the same principle. Those lobes and donuts in atomic diagrams are just regions of maximum amplitude in electron wavefunctions.

Don't worry about where the electrons "are". They're everywhere, because electrons are waves, not particles---at least when they're not being observed. They seem like particles when particle detectors detect them, but that doesn't mean they're particles when they're undisturbed. You can think of particle detectors as wave-squishing machines that temporarily force wave energy into a tiny volume. There are no point particles in quiescent atoms, only standing waves that are trapped in the electrostatic potential well created by the protons in the nucleus.

Oh yeah, those'll be easy to draw on a chalkboard. Look, think of one of those "cartoony" drawings of an atom as a "schematic." You don't like the schematic, that's fine, but don't disparage the thing. There's a reason engineers use both schematics and pictorial references, and a very good reason the schematics are the ones everyone uses for reference purposes. It's clear and explanatory and if you know how to read them, you can tell by looking at the device or circuit what goes where and what it does, even if you don't know the layout or even all the specific components. When I look at the 'schematic' for an atom, I know where all the parts are, what they do, and can look up further details for a given atom, assuming I haven't memorized them. Simpler versions are basically training wheels for everyone else.

What you want is a pictorial, which isn't really literally possible because the electrons refuse to stay still. So now you have a nice CG one to reference for your viewing pleasure. Unlike circuit pictorials it's probably not very useful - or maybe it is to someone. Not very practical though, since you can't print it out on a sheet of paper for handy reference.

While I like the video and love the models, I do have the problem with the premise of "a better way to picture atoms", because that lies entirely in what their intended use is. Yes, if one wants to picture what it actually looks like (as you do), it is better, but this is rarely the case.
More accurate isn't necessarily better. By the very nature of a model, it is a simplification of what it is portraying. A good model needs to find the balance between being accurate and being simply/easy to use. A globe is more accurate than a map, because it is in 3D, but that very same aspect often makes maps easier to use and therefore they become preferred models, because the inaccuracies doesn't matter or affect us, when we use them for their intended purpose.

Imagine if you made a video saying that a globe is a better way to picture earth, while technically true, people would probably say that you missed the point about maps. Especially if you gave a Minutephysics approved version of a map. The usefulness of this map would lie entirely in its projection and its intended use, so to say that this is a better version, is at best misleading and somewhat arrogant. You are comparing models that have different purposes and approve of yours as it fits your purpose, but that is hardly a fair assessment.

Meh, though beautiful, as a researcher in science education I am not too fond of that representation, but that would be actually a long story.
Let's take at least one example: You say that one dot, together with its trajectory represents where the electron might be and what velocity it has. But that is not correct. A dot represents where you might find an electron, if you care to measure its position, before measurement there is no electron with a specific position. And if you measure the position of the electron and it is at that one position, the velocity would be so gigantic, that it would just leave the nucleus.
So again, the representations are really really beautiful, but I fear the do not help with any misconceptions about atoms. Sorry.

Still that's not a correct depiction of an atom. It doesn't answer the most fundamental question which is this

"If you had an atom and you blew it up to the size of a bowling ball, what would it look like?"

The reason why you wouldn't be able to see atoms under any microscope that works with visible light, is because the wavelength of visible light is so much bigger than the atom itself. But if we were to blow up the atom to be the size of say... a bowling ball. Then that excuse doesn't apply anymore... Now the wavelength of visible light is smaller than the object we are observing (in this case the atom) and the atom is big enough so that we don't have to use microscopes... So what would it look like!?

The way I understand it. The atom will look like nothing. It will be completely invisible, just like the air... You know the air is there but you can't see it... Picture is like a spherical force field that you could probably touch (?) (although I don't really know what would happen to your hand if you do so...) and feel like something's there but you are unable to see it...

Other people suggest that it might emit light or radiation in general that you could see...

I wonder if it could have a surface and what would that feel and look like? Maybe it wouldn't have a surface in this case it might just be like I described it (an invisible ball of energy). Who knows?

But the reason this video is not answering the question is because what we picture here is the wave function of the atomic orbitals... That's like asking "how does a free kick in football look like" and showing me the equations that govern the trajectory of the ball after the player hit it plotted into a 4D space...

Thanks. That looks like it was a lot of work, and you did a great job with it! I really feel that we need more philosophy of science in the realm of quantum mechanics. We need to look QM in the eye and ask, 'What does this really mean?' I do think it would help if we stopped treating it like the old wave / particle duality idea, and started treated as a true quantum: a standing-wave packet that can (under certain conditions) behave like a single, independent thing. As a wave, it can spread out or it can contract, depending on circumstances. Clearly, this is where probability enters the picture. But it is also a self-contained unit, which is subject to the forces of nature - the fields - and can interact with them, as well as interacting with other wave quanta. Some phenomenon, such as tunneling, are not so mysterious if seen in this light. Of course, other ideas, such as non-locality, must still be dealt with. But let's chose this purely standing-wave quanta idea as a starting point, and go from there. It'll sure beat the heck out of 'Shut up and calculate!' tavi.

One thing I like about this approach with randomly-placed dots is that a few of them end up much further out than you usually see in diagrams. For instance, a diagram showing 95% probability will never show outliers, and it can give the wrong impression that there is some sharp boundary to a given orbital. There is no way to make that mistake with these animations. You also see the nodes in the same way, spaces with gradually decreasing numbers of dots, down to a middle where there are none at all.
